items.title: France's new prime minister resigns weeks after his appointment

items.title: Gold and copper prices surge and why you shouldn’t ignore your annual super statement

Plus, Japanese stocks have hit a record high just a day after the country’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party named Sanae Takaichi as its leader. For more, Rena Sarumpaet spoke with George Boubouras from K2 Asset Management. As annual superannuation statements start to arrive in the mail, Australians are being urged to not ignore them with research from Canstar showing about a fifth of respondents only check their super once every few years - or never. For more on how a financial health check could benefit your nest egg, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Canstar Data Insights Director Sally Tindall.

Around 1200 people were killed and 250 taken hostage during the designated terror group's attack on October 7, 2023, which triggered a brutal military response from Israel.

But this isn't the product of the fevered imagination of a Hollywood writer. This lone planet is very real.

Britain's rarest reptile, known as the Smooth Snake, is thriving again after conservation efforts were introduced to save it in 2009. But monitoring exactly how many Smooth Snakes there are can be a challenge due to the reptile's reclusive nature.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Everyone loves a ghost train: but why do we love being scared?
items.summary: Scary movies, haunted houses and trick or treating, October is the unofficial start to “spooky season” - at least, that's what you would think judging by what's on the shelves in our local shops. Sarah Kollat, teaching professor of psychology at Penn State University in the US, says there are lots of reasons people like to be scared. At a chemical level, our brains and bodies are reacting to the jump scares in a movie and “surviving” a haunted house. But psychologists also say getting scared in a safe environment prepares us for real danger.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Could a First Nations voice help tackle stubborn public health challenges?
items.summary: Nearly two years after the failed referendum saw a First Nations voice to parliament shot down, some NGOs and state governments have been taking the initiative to follow the wishes of the majority of Indigenous communities in Australia who voted for this special representation. Australia's principal non-government organisation for public health, the Public Health Association of Australia, has announced they will be instituting an Aboriginal and Torres-Strait Islander voice to help guide their work after a near unanimous vote by their members. SBS spoke to Dr Summer May Finlay, a Yorta Yorta woman, an Associate Professor at the University of Wollongong and the Vice President (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander) of the Public Health Association about the importance of a First Nations voice in helping to Close the Gap on healthcare outcomes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians

items.title: INTERVIEW: Israeli forces take action against flotilla trying to deliver aid
items.summary: Israeli military personnel have intercepted an international flotilla trying to deliver medicine and food to Gaza and boarded its boats as it approached the area. The Global Sumud Flotilla consists of more than 40 civilian boats carrying about 500 parliamentarians, lawyers and activists including Swedish climate campaigner Greta Thunberg. The organisers say they are trying to break Israel's blockade of Gaza, despite repeated warnings from Israel to turn back. The United Nations last month ruled that Israel had committed genocide in Gaza, a claim Israel denies. Israel has imposed a naval blockade on Gaza since Hamas took control of the coastal enclave in 2007 and they claim it is a legal part of the action they are taking against Hamas. They've accused the flotilla of having connections to Hamas - which the organisers strongly deny, while other critics accuse them of grandstanding. Judy Patterson's son, Hamish, is the captain of the Wahoo, one of the ships taking part in the action, and she spoke to SBS's Tee Mitchell.

items.title: Gaza peace plan, US shuts down & China combats whingers
items.summary: A new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza gains support among the international community. Trump warns the US military of the enemy from within as Hegseth tells Generals to slim down for the war on woke. Plus, Democrats and Republicans point the finger at each other as the US government shuts down. Also, Moscow warns of a new red line in the war in Ukraine. And, China launches a campaign to stamp out online negativity.

items.title: Australian men face loneliness crisis: what’s driving it and how to fix it
items.summary: Loneliness among men has been described as a "crisis" in Australia, and it appears to be on the rise. This social isolation can not only hurt mens mental health and overall wellbeing, it is also costing the Australian economy billions of dollars. A recent Australian study could hold the answer as to why men appear to be stuggling more with loneliness.

items.title: INTERVIEW: What does the US shutdown mean in practice?
items.summary: The U.S. federal government has entered a shutdown, a few hours after the U.S. Senate failed to pass a short-term spending bill on Tuesday night US East Coast time. It's the first government shutdown in nearly seven years. The last and also the longest federal government shutdown occurred from late 2018 to early 2019 during President Trump's first term when Democrats opposed funding the U.S.-Mexico border wall. The result was a shutdown lasting over five weeks, during which some 800,000 federal employees were forced to work without pay or take unpaid leave. Hundreds of thousands of federal employees will be forced to take unpaid leave this time too, with some public services potentially suspended or delayed, and the release of economic data possibly impacted as well. Bruce Wolpe is a senior fellow at the University of Sydney's United States Studies Centre and has served on the Democratic staff in the US Congress. He's been speaking to SBS's Virginia Langeberg about the impact of the shutdown.

items.title: A new First Nations voice to guide Australia's public health sector
items.summary: The Public Health Association of Australia has announced they will be establishing an Aboriginal and Torres-Strait Islander voice to help guide their work after a near unanimous vote by their members. Nearly two years after the failed referendum saw a First Nations voice to parliament shot down, NGOs like the PHAA and state governments have chosen to follow the wishes of the majority of Indigenous communities in Australia who voted for this special representation.

items.title: Helpful or spying? Do we really need to track where our loved ones are?
items.summary: Psychologists warn that the use of tracking apps like Life360 and FindMyPhone can normalise constant monitoring, which may start in families but spill into intimate partner relationships, potentially leading to controlling and coercive behaviours. But how do we know if tracking those we love is beneficial or problematic? And if it's the latter, how do we address it?

items.title: RBA holds fire; energy stock sell-off

For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Jonathan Shead, Head of Investment at State Street Investment Management. Plus, the Reserve Bank left interest rates unchanged at 3.6 percent, as expected, at its September board meeting. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Pradeep Philip from Deloitte Access Economics.

items.title: Optus faces backlash over triple-zero failures, with calls for consequences
items.summary: A meeting between Communications Minister Anika Wells and leaders from Optus and its parent company, Singtel, has yielded little new information or action. It comes as calls for stronger consequences grow in the wake of multiple triple-zero failures that have been linked to deaths. Critics say there's more the minister could be doing right now to restore public trust.

items.title: The PM's new supermarket proposal might cut your bills, but it's 'no silver bullet'
items.summary: The prime minister needs to consider preconditions, such as space and a break-up of Coles and Woolworths, if he wants a competing supermarket to thrive and bring down prices.

items.title: Key questions around the 'tone deaf, very tricky' Trump-Netanyahu Gaza peace plan
items.summary: A United States proposal for peace in Gaza has received endorsement from Israel and the Palestinian Authority, but its long-term success is on a knife-edge.

items.title: New guidelines developed for helping people with dementia
items.summary: A framework has been developed to track and improve the treatment options for dementia patients in aged care. The proposal come after the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare named dementia as the leading cause of death in Australia.

items.title: Middle East peace talks: US, Israel propose plan as Hamas weighs response
items.summary: Israel and the United States have agreed to a plan for ending the war in Gaza. But both US President Donald Trump and Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu have indicated if Hamas rejects the plan, the militant group will face the consequences. Hamas says it is reviewing the proposals.

items.title: 'Disappointing': Critics say Riyadh Comedy Festival has an unfunny human rights problem
items.summary: Comedy heavyweights including Dave Chappelle, Jimmy Carr and Louis CK are on the bill of the Riyadh Comedy Festival.

items.title: Not the outcome Australians wanted, Chalmers says, as Reserve Bank holds cash rate
items.summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia board was widely tipped to hold the cash rate after inflation data showed successive rises.

items.title: SBS News In Easy English 30 September 2025
items.summary: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

items.title: 'Hearts are aching': Family of missing preschooler release statement as search continues
items.summary: Four-year-old Gus disappeared from his family's remote South Australia property on Saturday afternoon.

items.title: The country under internet blackout after cables cut over 'vice' and immorality
items.summary: The country is experiencing a total connectivity blackout, according to Netblocks, the internet watchdog.

items.title: JK Rowling lashes out at 'ignorant' Emma Watson over trans rights row
items.summary: The author criticised the Harry Potter star, who said in a recent interview that she can still love people with whom she disagrees.

items.title: Albanese invites Arab 'hypermarket' to compete with Coles and Woolworths
items.summary: As Australia grapples with a supermarket monopoly, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese hopes the expansion of this Emirati "hypermarket" might bring in some competition.

items.title: Vital role of translators celebrated amid AI challenge
items.summary: It's been eight years since the United Nations first recognised International Translation Day. The celebration falls on 30 September and recognises the work of language professionals who foster cultural understanding, connection and social cohesion. But some translators and interpreters in Australia believe more needs to be done to protect the workforce and bridge language barriers.

items.title: Australia supports Trump's 20-point Gaza peace plan backed by Israel
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the country "welcomes President Trump's plan to bring peace to Gaza after almost two years of conflict and a devastating loss of civilian life".

items.title: Spouses for sale: Inside the black market for skilled visa applications
items.summary: SBS has uncovered a black market operating on apps targeting members of the Chinese community, selling places for "spouses" in permanent residency skilled visa applications.

items.title: 'They destroy lives': How property investors lost millions to a failed housing scheme
items.summary: A group of Iranians were told that investing in Australian specialist disability accommodation would be as safe as houses. However, those plans never eventuated, and they've collectively lost $1,178,500.

items.title: Dozens killed as Typhoon Bualoi batters Vietnam and Philippines
items.summary: In Vietnam, Bualoi made landfall as a typhoon late on Sunday, generating winds of 130 kmh.

items.title: Natural disasters are growing; could an army of young volunteers help?
items.summary: Could a 'Climate Army' of young volunteers bolster Australia's capability to cope with natural disasters? That's the question before a Senate inquiry looking at proposals for a new national scheme.

items.title: First Nations youth train as firefighters to defend Country and Community: 'I want to make a difference'
items.summary: A group of young First Nations men and women have blazed their way through a training program for firefighter hopefuls. The initiative is a partnership between TAFE and the New South Wales Fire Service - to help young Indigenous people get into their dream job.

items.title: Here are the travel destinations Australians are heading to this spring
items.summary: Many Australians will be heading out of state or the country this spring but cost is proving to be one of the greatest barriers for making plans.

items.title: Brisbane Broncos light up sharemarket & final budget outcome revealed
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Stephen Smith from Deloitte Access Economics abut what the government's final budget outcome says about the economy; plus Kyle Rodda from Capital.com on the day's sharemarket action.

items.title: What happened to an Australian republic? Why Albanese has quashed the idea
items.summary: The prime minister isn't willing to risk his renewed political capital by holding another referendum, experts argue.

items.title: Tony Blair: Ruler of Gaza? Why the former British leader is suddenly in the frame
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has praised former UK prime minister Tony Blair for his "constructive" involvement in the Middle East.

items.title: Moldova's pro-EU party wins surprise majority in election hit by Russian meddling claims
items.summary: The small European Union candidate nation has long been divided over whether to move closer with Brussels or maintain Soviet-era relations with Moscow.

items.title: Police pursuit ends in Bourke Street Mall, multiple arrests in Melbourne CBD
items.summary: Four teenagers have been arrested after police saw a vehicle being driven "erratically".

items.title: 'Weird weather': Why this year's spring and summer just became tricky to predict
items.summary: A clash of wind and air currents 30km above Antarctica has suddenly thrown Australia's spring and summer weather forecast into question.

items.title: Trump hints at Middle East peace plan: 'All on board for something special'
items.summary: The prospect of a long-awaited Middle East peace initiative has re-emerged, with President Donald Trump signalling that his administration is ready to unveil a comprehensive plan for Gaza. While US and Israeli leaders express cautious optimism, the humanitarian crisis in Gaza continues to worsen, with tens of thousands dead and entire neighbourhoods reduced to rubble.

items.title: SBS News In Easy English 29 September 2025
items.summary: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners, and people with a disability.

items.title: Calls mount for independent inquiry into Optus triple-zero failures
items.summary: The beleaguered telco revealed it's investigating yet another outage, with customers in NSW cut off from emergency calls over the weekend.

items.title: Jobs and wages boost budget bottom line ahead of Tuesday's interest rates call
items.summary: Strong jobs and wages numbers have more than halved the budget deficit that was projected last financial year.

items.title: 'In real danger': Hamas says it lost contact with two hostages during Israeli offensive
items.summary: Hamas's armed wing said the hostages' lives were under threat and called on Israeli forces to "immediately withdraw".

items.title: Working in a Gaza field hospital: The view from an Australian emergency nurse
items.summary: An Australian nurse is among the few international staff still on the ground at a Red Cross field hospital in southern Gaza. He shares the challenges of working in one of the only facilities still fully functioning in the enclave.

items.title: Four people dead, several injured after shooting at US Mormon church
items.summary: The suspect was shot dead by police after allegedly setting the building on fire.

items.title: In America's war on autism, families like Eileen's are on the frontline
items.summary: US health secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr has faced widespread criticism over his comments about autism. And in a changing America, community members from all parts of the spectrum are navigating societal and political divisions.

items.title: Nuclear bombs on drones: The next arms race that has experts 'very concerned'
items.summary: While drones flying over different parts of Europe have raised concerns in many countries, some are worried about a more dystopian future with the technology.

items.title: 'Part of my job': Albanese fires back at critics questioning his taxpayer-funded UK itinerary
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese addressed concerns about participating in a party-political event in an interview with SBS News.

items.title: Russia's major drone and missile attack on Ukraine kills four in Kyiv
items.summary: Russia rained down 643 drones and missiles, including glide bombs, across eastern, central and southern Ukraine, Ukraine's general staff said.

items.title: What to know about UN's 'snapback' sanctions on Iran, reimposed after a decade
items.summary: The "snapback" process reactivates UN resolutions, but their practical implementation requires UN member states to update their laws to comply.

items.title: The hidden form of sexual assault you may not know about
items.summary: Stealthing — the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent — is criminalised in most of Australia. But experts warn many people remain unaware of what it is and the risks it poses.

items.title: The hidden form of sexual assault you may not know about
items.summary: Stealthing — the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent — is criminalised in most of Australia. But experts warn many people remain unaware of what it is and the risks it poses.

items.title: Donald Trump deploys troops into another US city, authorising use of 'full force, if necessary'
items.summary: The Portland mayor and Oregon governor have both rejected Donald Trump's planned deployment of the US military into the north-western city.

items.title: Russia says West will 'very much regret' any aggressive action inside its airspace
items.summary: The Russian foreign minister also said that only the "politically blind" would expect Ukraine to return to pre-2022 borders, an indirect response to a recent assertion made by the US president.

items.title: The effects of Tonga's massive volcanic explosion linger, three years on
items.summary: It's been more than three and a half years since one of the most powerful volcanic eruptions in recent history left devastation in Tonga. An Australian-led scientific team has been studying the area surrounding the underwater volcano, in collaboration with researchers from across the world, looking for signs of life. The eruption changed the shape of the sea floor and devastated the underwater environment but early signs of life are beginning to emerge.

items.title: MSF suspends Gaza City health activities as Hamas denies reports of an in-principle truce
items.summary: Hamas has contradicted a prominent Israeli newspaper's report that it had agreed in principle to a truce deal proposed by the US president.

items.title: INTERVIEW: 'We are family, we should work together': Palau President's challenge to Australia
items.summary: Palau, an independent island nation in the western Pacific Ocean, consists of more than 300 islands in Micronesia. It's a popular destination for divers and ecotourists and visitors are required to take the "Palau Pledge" to protect its ecosystems. But Palau is already facing the immediate reality of climate change, with rising sea levels, coral bleaching, extreme weather events, and biodiversity loss. Surangel Whipps Junior, the President of Palau, has spoken at the United Nations General Assembly in New York, and wants to see the COP31 global climate conference held in the Pacific region rather than in Turkiye, because this is where climate change is already having devastating impacts. He's been talking to SBS Senior International Correspondent Ben Lewis, and told him that Palau and Australia are family - and the two countries need to work together.

items.title: 'Jekyll and Hyde': How to win over Australia's most polarising bird
items.summary: Culturally revered in Dreamtime stories but feared by cyclists, the magpie has a "Jekyll and Hyde" presence in our suburbs. But one expert says there are ways to win them over — even if you're magpie enemy number one.

items.title: 'Peeling back the water': How these women are mapping ancient whale migration paths
items.summary: A trio of First Nations researchers is blending traditional knowledge and science to map whale migration and advocate for improved conservation.

items.title: New Zealand won't recognise a Palestinian state 'at this time'
items.summary: The decision puts the country at odds with its Commonwealth allies Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom.

items.title: 'Is this still happening?': Elon Musk named in new Epstein files
items.summary: Prince Andrew and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel are among the other names in the documents released by Democrat politicians.

items.title: Afraid of AI replacing you? Here are jobs that may be future-proof
items.summary: Jobs including tax preparation, legal advice and education may have the lowest risk of being replaced by technology.

items.title: Trump isn't the first to push an unproven claim about autism. Why are they so pervasive?
items.summary: One expert says an "information void" has allowed non-evidence-based claims and conspiracy theories around autism to flourish.

items.title: Six-pack diplomacy: Albanese joins Starmer and Carney for high-stakes talks
items.summary: The Australian, British and Canadian leaders used a London summit to warn against the far-right and to discuss migration and renewed support for Palestinian statehood.

items.title: How to deep clean your fridge ahead of summer
items.summary: Those neglected items at the back of your fridge can become a health hazard.

items.title: New deep space antenna in Australia to aid exploration of universe while also creating local jobs
items.summary: More than three years after it was first announced, a new deep space antenna is being brought online in Western Australia.

items.title: Dozens walk out on Netanyahu UN speech calling Palestinian recognition a 'mark of shame'
items.summary: A procession of delegates exited the United Nations General Assembly hall ahead of Benjamin Netanyahu's speech denouncing Australia, France, Britain, Canada and other countries for recognising a Palestinian state.

items.title: What's next for South Australia's algae bloom?
items.summary: South Australia's algal bloom continues to spread, leading to significant environmental, ecological and mental health harm. Those impacts have been heard at a Senate inquiry examining support arrangements for those affected, but also long-term prevention strategies.

items.title: Australia has around 100,000 eggs in IVF storage. Some want to see unclaimed eggs donated
items.summary: The demand for eggs far outpaces the number donated in Australia, leaving those wanting to start families with few options. Experts say something needs to change.

items.title: Dreaming of spreadsheets and battling stage fright: Behind the world Excel championships
items.summary: From spreadsheets to showdowns, the Excel World Championship turns number-crunching into a high-stakes spectacle.

items.title: How a radical three-month experiment changed Australia's TV landscape forever
items.summary: Celebrating five decades on air, a landmark SBS documentary shows how a radical idea evolved into a national platform for Indigenous and multicultural storytelling.

items.title: Pharma stocks tumble following US pharma import tariffs
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP and Marcus Bogdan from Blackmore Capital about the reaction to a US decision to apply 100% import tariffs to pharmaceutical products from Wednesday, plus all the latest from the sharemarket.

items.title: What time does the 2025 AFL grand final start? All the key details to know
items.summary: Around 100,000 people are anticipated to go to the Geelong v Brisbane match this weekend.

items.title: 'Exclusion or punishment': Fears of a growing problem in Australian schools
items.summary: There's an anti-Palestinian racism "crisis" in Australian schools, according to a new report by an advocacy group, with students and teachers being punished for showing support for the Palestinian cause.

items.title: UN says millions of young people are being left behind
items.summary: Youth advocates from around the world have gathered at the UN headquarters in New York to participate in the high-level plenary meeting of the General Assembly. Their meeting marked the thirtieth anniversary of the World Programme of Action for Youth.

items.title: Butler criticises Trump's 'unfair' pharma tariffs that Ley says are 'shocking but unsurprising'
items.summary: Medicines and pharmaceuticals are among Australia's top exports to the US, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

items.title: Who is James Comey, the Trump critic and ex-FBI director who has just been indicted?
items.summary: James Comey, who was fired by Donald Trump during the US president's first term, has been charged with two criminal counts.

items.title: 'Unusual': Passenger on board Qantas flight speaks after emergency landing
items.summary: The plane landed safely at Auckland Airport after concerns of a fire in the cargo hold. The local ambulance service said no passengers on board required its assistance.

items.title: Donald Trump says any Israeli annexation of the West Bank is 'not going to happen'
items.summary: The US president has rejected calls from some members of the Israeli prime minister's coalition for Israel to fully annex the West Bank.

items.title: 'Unauthorised' edit of Australian film Together removes same-sex couple for audiences in China
items.summary: The film Together has reportedly been altered using artificial intelligence by a Chinese film distributor.

items.title: Palestinian leader condemns Israel's assault on Gaza, rejects Hamas during UN address
items.summary: Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas addressed the UN General Assembly via video, accusing Israel of war crimes and declaring that Hamas will have no future role in governing Gaza.

items.title: From Silicon Valley to Sydney: How Trump's H-1B visa move could make ripples in Australia
items.summary: As Donald Trump's H-1B visa order seeks to restrict the United States' intake of skilled migrants, could it provide an opportunity for Australia?

items.title: Australia's battle to take out a rival bid and host its 'biggest diplomatic summit ever'
items.summary: The summit would likely provide an economic boost for the hopeful host city, Adelaide, after a record 80,000 people attended last year's event in Dubai.

items.title: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy jailed for five years over Libyan criminal conspiracy case
items.summary: Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to obtain campaign financing.

items.title: Industries at risk of technology and AI & big dividend day
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves delves into Barrenjoey's report on the industries most exposed to technological change and AI with Johnathan McMenamin; plus the day on the sharemarket with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets.

items.title: Special Episode: Palestine recognition, Trump unfiltered & paracetamol panic
items.summary: Ten Western nations (including Australia, the UK, and France) formally recognise a Palestinian state at the UN General Assembly. Our correspondents bring you the latest from New York, as they break down the statehood debate, MAGA’s escalating war on the left, and Trump’s unsubstantiated claims linking paracetamol and autism.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Penny Wong on the upcoming Albanese-Trump meeting and Australia's bid to host COP31
items.summary: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the upcoming meeting between Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump will seek to advance areas of co-operation but also underline issues of sovereignty.

items.title: It's 'third time lucky' for an Alzheimer's drug. But many Australians like Peter will miss out
items.summary: Australia's medicines watchdog has approved Alzheimer's drug lecanemab, which has been shown to "significantly" extend quality of life. But it comes at a great cost.

items.title: 'Thanks for waking me up': Untold story behind Cathy Freeman's Olympic glory

items.summary: Anthony Albanese has met Donald Trump at the president's welcome reception for world leaders in New York after the pair locked in a formal sit-down for October.

items.title: Greta Thunberg calls alleged drone attacks on aid flotilla a 'scare tactic' as UN demands probe
items.summary: The United Nations has called for an independent investigation into alleged drone attacks on the Global Sumud Flotilla, an international convoy carrying humanitarian aid to Gaza.
